abstract:
Abstract
We revisit the classic problem of optimal subset selection in the online learning set-up. Assume that the set [N]delimited-[]ùëÅ[N] consists of NùëÅN distinct elements. On the tùë°tth round, an adversary chooses a monotone reward function ft:2[N]‚Üí‚Ñù+:subscriptùëìùë°‚Üísuperscript2delimited-[]ùëÅsubscript‚Ñùf_{t}:2^{[N]}\to\mathbb{R}_{+} that assigns a non-negative reward to each subset of [N].delimited-[]ùëÅ[N]. An online policy selects (perhaps randomly) a subset St‚äÜ[N]subscriptùëÜùë°delimited-[]ùëÅS_{t}\subseteq[N] consisting of kùëòk elements before the reward function ftsubscriptùëìùë°f_{t} for the tùë°tth round is revealed to the learner. As a consequence of its choice, the policy receives a reward of ft‚Äã(St)subscriptùëìùë°subscriptùëÜùë°f_{t}(S_{t}) on the tùë°tth round. Our goal is to design an online sequential subset selection policy to maximize the expected cumulative reward accumulated over a time horizon. In this connection, we propose an online learning policy called SCore (Subset Selection with Core) that solves the problem for a large class of reward functions. The proposed SCore policy is based on a new polyhedral characterization of the reward functions called Œ±ùõº\alpha-Core - a generalization of Core from the cooperative game theory literature. We establish a learning guarantee for the SCore policy in terms of a new performance metric called Œ±ùõº\alpha-augmented regret. In this new metric, the performance of the online policy is compared with an unrestricted offline benchmark that can select all NùëÅN elements at every round. We show that a large class of reward functions, including submodular, can be efficiently optimized with the SCore policy. We also extend the proposed policy to the optimistic learning set-up where the learner has access to additional untrusted hints regarding the reward functions. Finally, we conclude the paper with a list of open problems.
